awd_titl_txt: Binary Expansion Statistics: A Nonparametric Inference Framework for Big Data
awd_abstract_narration:
In the Big Data era, the large numbers of observations and variables pose unprecedented challenging problems of complex forms of dependency and high computing expenses. This situation is especially common in important problems in Astronomy, Biology, Economics, Engineering, Finance, Genetics, Genomics, Neurosciences, etc. To meet these challenges, the PI proposes to study these problems through a novel framework of binary expansion statistics. The overall objective of the project is (i) to provide an in-depth understanding of complex dependency in Big Data with new theory and methods, and (ii) to build a stronger connection between Statistics and Computer Science. The PI anticipates the achievement of his goals through an integration of research and education plans.


The binary expansion statistics framework is able to "divide and conquer" any complex dependency, i.e., to approximate and decompose nonlinear dependency into interactions of Bernoulli variables in the binary expansion filtration and then aggregate the information to produce nonparametric inference of dependence. This approach connects the inference problems to important concepts in Statistics and Computer Science such as multiple testing, Hadamard transform, and bitwise operation. The research agenda is to further develop this framework and study several fundamental problems to develop optimal theory, methodologies and algorithms. The PI also has comprehensive plans on educating graduate and undergraduate students and on disseminating the research results to the broader scientific community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In the Big Data era, the large numbers of observations and variables pose unprecedented challenging problems of complex forms of dependency and high computing expenses. To meet these challenges, the PI proposes to study these problems with the novel framework of binary expansion statistics. This approach can “divide and conquer” any complex dependency, i.e., to approximate and decompose nonlinear dependency into interactions of Bernoulli variables in the binary expansion filtration and then aggregate the information to provide nonparametric inference of dependence. The first paper on this approach has demonstrated its potential with powerful, interpretable, and computationally efficient nonparametric procedures.

In this project, the PI further developed this framework and studied several fundamental problems to establish optimal theory, methodologies and algorithms. In the funded three years, the PI has published 13 papers on the proposed research. The PI also 4 four graduate students and on disseminating the research results to the broader scientific community to advance knowledge in many areas of science.

Intellectual merits:  In the funded studies, the novel binary expansion statistics framework brought in new understanding and ideas to the development of theory and methods on nonparametric inference, as they provided accurate approximation of the joint distribution while connecting the inference problem to important concepts in statistics and computer science such as multiple testing, Hadamard transform and bitwise operation. The filtration approach guaranteed the universal and uniform consistency of the procedures, the interaction of Bernoulli variables provided clear interpretations of dependency, and the connection between the proposed binary expansion statistics and bits in current computing systems helped the development of computationally efficient algorithms. Results from the proposed research has provided a comprehensive understanding of nonparametric inference for dependence and a stronger connection between statistics and computer science.

Broader impacts: The proposed projects will directly benefit society in many ways: For the broader scientific community, since the proposed framework assumes only (i) the observations are i.i.d. and (ii) the variables are continuous, the new procedures were widely applicable for Big Data research in many scientific areas and served as the basis of several collaborations. The PI also developed efficient software packages and algorithms and made them freely and publicly available.

For students, the PI has supervised the research of 4 Ph.D. students (two female) based on this project. The PI also integrated the proposed research in courses and research projects to equip students with fundamental ideas in Big Data analysis. In all funded research and educational activities, the PI has paid special attention to help female students and students from underrepresented groups.
